Author Contributions A.F. and P.A. conceived and designed the study; A.F. performed mouse
experiments, immunofluorescence, ELISA, ribosomal profiling, and
bioinformatics; H-J.P and A.F. prepared primary cell cultures; J.L. and L.A.
performed single-nuclei sequencing; A.F. and L.A. performed and S.A., S.S.,
M.V., D.A.-K., D.M.R., and T.N. assisted qPCR, Western blotting, and
immunocytochemistry; J.M. performed protein aggregation and uptake
experiments; M-E.T. designed and supervised, P.K performed, and C.S.,
F.G.I., O.B., assisted EM experiments; P.D. and N.J.H. designed and P.D.
performed the lipidomics analysis; J.D.M. and S.W. performed VGLUT2 imaging;
J.W.M. wrote ImageJ macros and guided image analysis; S.M. and A.F.
performed mouse surgeries; M.P. provided human tissue and guided human
electron microscopy experiments; A.F. and P.A. wrote, and all authors edited
the manuscript. * payata@gc.cuny.edu Declaration of interests The authors declare no competing interests. 19 2 2025 23 12 2024 113 4 497820 554 571.e14 05 09 2025 30 09 2025 01 10 2025 01 10 2025 Summary The brain’s primary immune cells, microglia, are a leading causal
cell type in Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Yet, the mechanisms by which
microglia can drive neurodegeneration remain unresolved. Here we discover that a
conserved stress signaling pathway, the integrated stress response (ISR),
characterizes a microglia subset with neurodegenerative outcomes. Autonomous
activation of ISR in microglia is sufficient to induce early features of the
ultrastructurally distinct “dark microglia” linked to pathological
synapse loss. In AD models, microglial ISR activation exacerbates
neurodegenerative pathologies and synapse loss while its inhibition ameliorates
them. Mechanistically, we present evidence that ISR activation promotes the
secretion of toxic lipids by microglia, impairing neuron homeostasis and
survival in vitro. Accordingly, pharmacological inhibition of ISR or lipid
synthesis mitigates synapse loss in AD models. Our results demonstrate that
microglial ISR activation represents a neurodegenerative phenotype, which may be
sustained, at least in part, by the secretion of toxic lipids.
